The impact of Internet speed on business productivity: how much bandwidth does your company really need?

When it comes to Internet services, it’s all about speed and reliability. A slow connection not only damages the overall customer experience, but it also lowers your overall company’s productivity. Internet services are critical for your daily operations and tasks such as: internal communications, data file transfers, inventory management, and point of sales applications. Without it, businesses wouldn’t be able to provide fast customer service or keep up with the pace of innovation and growth.

 

There are services to fit almost everything: from a small office with basic email and web browsing needs, to a multinational enterprise with more than 400 employees and that transfers large amounts of data and video conference meetings. In order to find the right Internet solution for your company, it’s critical to identify the steps in assessing your business’ needs. Here’s a quick guide to make sure you’re getting the bandwidth that your company really needs:

 

How does your business use technology?

 

The way your business utilizes technology will assist you in choosing the right Internet speed. You may only have a few employees in your workplace, but if your business has complex technology needs such as: online payments, video conferencing and e-commerce, you’ll need a higher bandwidth connection. It’s also important to identify the number of devices that your company uses on a daily basis – including your employees’ smart phones, tablets and other mobile devices that requires connectivity.

Understanding upload and download speeds

 

While business leaders are usually concerned about the speed that your devices can pull data from the Internet (download speed), upload can be more vital to your daily operations – since it determines how quick you can send out the information (i.e. uploading attachments and sending emails). If the connection is slower than expected, your company’s daily tasks will become very slow and inefficient.

 

What business leaders should consider when choosing an Internet services provider?

 

Can your services provider deliver what your business need? Whenever you lose connectivity you risk losing money and customers. While your provider cannot control outages that occur from bad weather or considerable network congestion, its reliability and reach will control how fast they can get your business up and running.

 

How fast can they recover from service outages and disruptions? The average cost to small and medium businesses due to Internet disruptions is approximately $6,900 per hour, according to a study developed by Aberdeen Research Group. How reliable is your provider’s network? Preferably, the provider you choose will deliver redundant coverage throughout the Island. If your main connection goes down, you have to be able to connect to resources and keep your business functioning without interruptions.

 

Undoubtedly, a slow connection translates in unsatisfied consumers, less profit, and operational inefficiencies. “Business leaders can’t continue viewing technology as an exclusive task of the IT department, but rather as a critical subject for those responsible of decision making,” stated David Bogaty, President and CEO at WorldNet. Bogaty emphasized on the need for leaders to have a strategic vision so as to avoid falling into a technology trap. “Leaders need to make sure they aren’t over-investing or acquiring the wrong technology for their businesses. Instead, they should invest strategically aligning new technology to business goals” he added.

 

Broadband technologies should meet your company’s current bandwidth needs, but it should be positioned to meet future needs as well. When it comes to telecommunications services, you may want to partner with an expert, and allow them to show you how to choose the right solution to accelerate your business growth.
